channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Supreme Court Curbs Judges in Birthright Case as Trump Touts Win
item.description: A sharply divided US Supreme Court limited the power of judges to block government policies nationwide but left unresolved a fight over President Donald Trump’s restrictions on automatic birthright citizenship.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian holding a baby outside the US Supreme Court in Washington, DC. Photographer: Sarah Silbiger/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says July 4 Tax-Cut Bill Deadline Isn’t the ‘End All’ Date
item.description: President Donald Trump said that his self-imposed July 4 goal to pass his tax bill isn’t an absolute deadline, remarks that give Republican negotiators additional breathing room as lawmakers remain at loggerheads over several issues in the massive economic package.
item.dc:creator: Cam Kettles, Erik Wasson, Alicia Diaz, Maeve Sheehey

media:content.media:description: Visitors in the rotunda at the US Capitol in Washington DC, US, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. The White House amped up the pressure on Republicans on Wednesday urging lawmakers to quickly approve President Donald Trump’s signature tax bill, adding that a failure to do so would be the “ultimate betrayal.”

item.title: Putin Says Russia to Seek Defense Cuts; How Much Depends on War
item.description: President Vladimir Putin said Russia plans to cut defense spending, acknowledging growing strains on the budget even as he insisted that reductions would depend on winning his war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Russian T-90M tanks drive through central Moscow during a rehearsal for the Victory Day parade, on May 3.

item.title: Canada’s Digital Services Tax Stays in Place Despite G-7 Deal
item.description: Canada is proceeding with its digital services tax on technology companies such as Meta Platforms Inc. despite a Group of Seven agreement that resulted in removing the Section 899 “revenge tax” proposal from US President Donald Trump’s tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin

media:content.media:description: Parliament Hill in Ottawa.

item.title: Supreme Court Bolsters Religious Rights in LGBTQ Book Case
item.description: The US Supreme Court said public school parents have a right to opt out of classroom lessons that intrude on their religious beliefs, ruling that a Maryland county probably violated the Constitution by using LGBTQ-friendly books without notice to parents.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr, Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Supporters advocating for religious rights demonstrate outside the US Supreme Court Building in Washington, DC, on April 22.

item.title: California Democrats Push Reforms to Prevent Refinery Shutdowns
item.description: A group of California Democrats is looking to ease the state’s gasoline standards and streamline permitting for refineries in a bid to prevent more fuelmakers from shutting down and raising costs for the state’s drivers.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: A refinery in Wilmington, California.

item.title: Albania Takes Stake in Jared Kushner’s $1.4 Billion Tourism Plan
item.description: Albania established a state-owned company to take a stake in a $1.4 billion luxury resort project led by Jared Kushner, Donald Trump’s son-in-law.
item.dc:creator: Gresa Kraja

media:content.media:description: Tourists visit the St. Mary's Monastery on Zvrnec island in Vlora, Albania.

item.title: Romanian Leader Pledges More Budget Measures to Curb Deficit
item.description: Romania’s premier outlined fresh measures to cut the ballooning budget deficit as the new government seeks to safeguard the country’s investment-grade rating and ease investor concern.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Designated Prime Minister Ilie Bolojan gives a joint press statement with the Romanian President at Cotroceni Palace, the Romanian Presidency's headquarters, in Bucharest June 20, 2025.

item.title: Tusk Says Ballot Recount Shouldn’t Reverse Presidential Vote
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk said suspected voting irregularities in the country’s June 1 presidential election were unlikely to lead to a reversal of the victory of nationalist Karol Nawrocki.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, Mayor of Warsaw and candidate for President of Poland, center, and Donald Tusk, Poland's prime minister, right, march with supporters in the Great Patriots March along Marszalkowska Street in Warsaw, Poland, on Sunday, May 25, 2025. The slump in Polish stocks, one of the year’s global equity standouts, signals that traders are increasingly jittery about any more political surprises.

item.title: Wealthy Silicon Valley Investors In Line for $17 Billion Windfall in GOP Tax Bill
item.description: Silicon Valley’s favorite tax break may be getting an upgrade.
item.dc:creator: Ben Steverman

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Senate Republicans intend to propose revised tax and health-care provisions to President Donald Trump's $3 trillion signature economic package this week, shrugging off condemnations of the legislation by Elon Musk as they rush to enact it before July 4.

item.title: Supreme Court Upholds $8.6 Billion FCC Telecom Subsidy Fund
item.description: The US Supreme Court upheld the $8.6 billion Universal Service Fund, the annual slate of subsidies that helps cover the cost of telecom services for low-income people, rural residents, schools and libraries.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent Says Push for Trade Deals Could Wrap Up by Sept. 1
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the Trump administration’s agenda for trade agreements could get wrapped up by the Labor Day holiday, indicating some negotiations are likely to extend past the upcoming July deadline for elevated reciprocal tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, speaks to members of the media following a meeting with lawmakers at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Bessent and congressional Republicans are meeting to sketch out the plan for passing a multi-trillion tax cut in the coming weeks as polling shows that voters largely disapprove of the White House’s handling of the economy.

item.title: EU, US Confident They’ll Reach Tariff Deal by July Deadline
item.description: The European Union and the US believe they can clinch some form of a trade agreement before a July 9 deadline, when Washington is set to impose a 50% tariff on nearly all EU products and the bloc plans to unleash its own series of countermeasures.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: The Port of Rotterdam in Rotterdam, Netherlands, in April. Photographer: Lina Selg/Bloomberg

item.title: Why Iran’s Unaccounted for Uranium Worries Nuclear Experts
item.description: For those concerned about Iran becoming a nuclear-armed state, it’s essential to understand not just what the attacks by the US and Israel did to the country’s capacity to enrich uranium, but also what’s become of its existing inventory of atomic fuel.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

item.title: Greek Migration Minister Resigns Over Allegations on EU Funds
item.description: Greek Migration Minister Makis Voridis resigned amid revelations about alleged irregularities related to European funds for agriculture, while denying any wrongdoing.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas

media:content.media:description: Minister of Migration and Asylum Makis Voridis

item.title: Charismatic Communist Shakes Up Chile’s Presidential Primary
item.description: Just over a hundred years after its creation, Chile’s Communist Party may have unexpectedly found one of its best-ever presidential hopefuls.
item.dc:creator: Valentina Fuentes, Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Jeannette Jara, presidential candidate for the Communist Party of Chile, speaks after registering her candidacy at the Electoral Service of Chile in Santiago, Chile, on Wednesday, April 30, 2025.

item.title: Merz Tells EU Leaders to Beware Growing Dangers of a Debt Crisis
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz warned European Union leaders that the mounting debts of governments and companies are fueling the risk of a new financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Germany's chancellor Friedrich Merz

item.title: Why Kenya Has Been Rocked by Anti-Government Protests Again
item.description: Kenya was racked by nationwide protests and clashes that left at least 16 people dead and hundreds injured in late June.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek, David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators in downtown Nairobi on June 25, 2025.

item.title: East African Countries Face Broad Crackdown on Political Dissent
item.description: When thousands of young Kenyans converged across the nation this week to mark a year since scores of them were killed in protests, police were ready and opened fire, leaving at least 16 dead.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Protesters hold Kenyan flags during a demonstration in Nairobi on June 25. Photographer: Gerald Anderson/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: US Energy Chief Says Goal for Iran Is Making a Peace Deal
item.description: US Energy Secretary Chris Wright hedged when asked about a US “maximum pressure” campaign against Iran, shifting the focus of his answer to looking toward a peace deal.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: US secretary of energy Chris Wright

item.title: Planned Belgrade Trump Tower Slammed by Europe Heritage Watchdog
item.description: Serbia must protect its monuments and defy plans by Donald Trump’s son-in-law to raze downtown blocs in the nation’s capital to make way for a large real estate project, said Europe’s top cultural heritage organization.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: The former Yugoslavia Ministry of Defence building in Belgrade, Serbia.

item.title: UK Budget Reversals Threaten Reeves as Well as Her Fiscal Rules
item.description: Labour’s costly climbdowns on big policy plans don’t just leave Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves with the dilemma of how to find the money to meet her budget rules. They’re also starting to raise questions about her own job security.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Joe Mayes, Freya Jones

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves and Keir Starmer on June 23. Photographer: Jacob King/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Turkey Set to Skip Minimum-Wage Hike in Boost for Investors
item.description: Turkey’s government plans to skip a mid-year increase in the minimum wage, according to people with knowledge of the matter, resisting political pressure to alleviate rising living costs.
item.dc:creator: Firat Kozok, Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: Workers clean the floor of a self service cafe area in Ankara, Turkey, on Monday, on June 26, 2023. The Turkish lira has depreciated by nearly 18% against the dollar this month.

item.title: Cuomo Won’t Quit NYC Mayor’s Race Before Ballot Deadline
item.description: Andrew Cuomo has no plans to drop out of the New York City mayor’s race by a Friday deadline, according to a person familiar with the matter, meaning that his name will appear on the ballot in November as an independent.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Workers dismantle the stage following New York City mayoral candidate Andrew Cuomo's election-night watch party in New York, on June 24,

item.title: Prabowo Set to Attend BRICS Summit After Indonesia Joins Bloc
item.description: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto is set to attend the BRICS summit next month in Brazil, marking his first meeting with the bloc since the Southeast Asian nation became a member this year, according to officials familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Prabowo Subianto

item.title: Senate Gun, Silencer Provisions Blocked From Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans’ effort to use President Donald Trump’s massive tax bill to eliminate regulations on short-barreled rifles, short-barreled shotguns and silencers has hit a roadblock with the chamber’s rules-keeper.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: A firearm silencer at a National Rifle Association meeting in Houston, Texas.

item.title: South Africa’s Ramaphosa Says He Asked DA for New Deputy Minister
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa said he asked the leader of the second-biggest party in the country’s coalition to pick a replacement for one of its officials that he fired from his executive as a deputy minister.
item.dc:creator: Ana Monteiro

media:content.media:description: South Africa's president Cyril Ramaphosa

item.title: Miami Chafes at Trump’s ICE Raids and ‘Alligator Alcatraz’
item.description: For months, unease over President Donald Trump’s immigration dragnet had been building in Miami, which has a larger share of foreign-born residents than any major city in America.
item.dc:creator: Anna J Kaiser, Michael Smith, Fabiola Zerpa

media:content.media:description: Trailers at an immigration detention facility dubbed “Alligator Alcatraz”at an isolated Everglades airfield, in this image grab from video. WSVN/AP

item.title: US Pushes for Economic Pact in Congo-Rwanda Peace Agreement
item.description: A US-brokered peace deal between Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda will include the outlines of a separate economic integration pact between the two nations — to be concluded within three months, people with direct knowledge of the talks said.
item.dc:creator: Michael J Kavanagh

media:content.media:description: M23 rebels in Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, in April.

item.title: Thai Finance Minister Heads to US for Trade Talks Next Week
item.description: Thai Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira will visit the US next week for tariff negotiations in an attempt to clinch a trade deal ahead of Washington’s deadline on July 9.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: Pichai Chunhavajira Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg
